problem:
There exists a polynomial $P$ of degree 5 with the following property: If $z$ is a complex number such that $z^5 + 2004z = 1,$ then $P(z^2) = 0.$  Calculate
\[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}.\]
model_solution:
Step 1: Let $Q(w) = P(\sqrt{w}) + P(-\sqrt{w}).$
$Q$ is a polynomial of degree 10 with real coefficients.
Since $P(z^2)=0$ when $z^5+2004z=1$, we have $\sqrt{w}^5+2004\sqrt{w}=1$ and $-\sqrt{w}^5-2004(-\sqrt{w})=1$ when $w>0$
\[\left(\sqrt{w}\right)^5+2004\left(\sqrt{w}\right)=1\]
\[\left(-\sqrt{w}\right)^5-2004\left(-\sqrt{w}\right)=1\]
Step 2:
$Q\left(1\right)=P\left(\sqrt{1}\right)+P\left(-\sqrt{1}\right)=P\left(1\right)+P\left(-1\right)$ and $Q\left(-1\right)=P\left(\sqrt{-1}\right)+P\left(-\sqrt{-1}\right)$
$=P\left(i\right)+P\left(-i\right)$
Step 3:
$Q(-1) = P(\sqrt{-1}) + P(-\sqrt{-1}) = P(i) + P(-i) = 0$ since $-i^5 + 2004(-i) = -1 + 2004i = 1$, so $i^5 + 2004i = 1$, which is impossible, so $P(i) = 0$.
$\sqrt{-1} = i$ and $\sqrt{-1} = -i$, so $P(i) = P(-i) = 0.$
Step 4:
Since $Q(-1)=0$, we have $P(1)+P(-1)=0$ so $P(1)=-P(-1)$.
Step 5:
$\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{-P(-1)}{P(-1)}.$
$\frac{-P(-1)}{P(-1)}.$
Step 6:
$\frac{-P(-1)}{P(-1)} = -1.$
Step 7:
\[-1.\]
Step 8:
$\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = -1.$
Step 9:
$\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = -1.$

full_steps:
Step 1: Let $Q(w) = P(\sqrt{w}) + P(-\sqrt{w}).$
$Q$ is a polynomial of degree 10 with real coefficients.
Since $P(z^2)=0$ when $z^5+2004z=1$, we have $\sqrt{w}^5+2004\sqrt{w}=1$ and $-\sqrt{w}^5-2004(-\sqrt{w})=1$ when $w>0$
\[\left(\sqrt{w}\right)^5+2004\left(\sqrt{w}\right)=1\]
\[\left(-\sqrt{w}\right)^5-2004\left(-\sqrt{w}\right)=1\]
